title: About
text: I am a sixth year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Ecology and Resource Management program at the University of Washington. My research focuses on applying spatiotemporal statistical models to questions in fisheries management and ecology. In particular, I am developing models for indices of abundance that include fishery-dependent observations. I am also interested in improving the computational efficiency and reliability of Bayesian model fits through the application of advanced Markov chain Monte Carlo tools like the No-U-Turn Sampler. Prior to graduate school I worked in aviation maintenance and the outdoor industry.

title: John K. Best
text: When I’m not working I spend time with my family, play with my dog, run, and learn about whatever new and exciting hobby I’ve more recently found.

title: Introduction to Hyak
section: How to choose a node type

title: Introduction to Hyak
text:
Request an interactive node

build node:


srun -p build --mem=10G --time=1:00:00 --pty /bin/bash

stf-int node:


srun -p stf-int -A stf --cpus-per-task=28 --mem=120G\
    --time=1:00:00 --pty /bin/bash

title: Introduction to Hyak
text:
Relevant SLURM arguments

srun

Request in interactive node

sbatch

Submit a batch job

-p

Partition; node type to use

-A

Account; usually stf

--cpus-per-task

Threads per program

--tasks-per-node

Processes to run on each node

--nodes

Number of nodes to request

--mem

Amount of RAM to request

--time

Time to reserve

--pty

Program to start

title: Introduction to Hyak
text:
Connecting a second time
To see which node you are using:
squeue -u jkbest
  JOBID PARTITION ... NODELIST(REASON)
1838469     build ... n2232
From login node:
ssh n2232
Now monitor usage with e.g. htop

text:

module --help

Reminders

module load abcdef

Attach module abcdef

module unload abcdef

Detach module abcdef

title: Introduction to Hyak
text:
Using a build node

Request a build node.
Load the appropriate R module (or have your custom version accessible).
Run R at the command line to open R.
Use install.packages to install what you need.

title: Introduction to Hyak
text:
Using an stf-int node

Request an stf-int node (see above).
Load the R module.
Open R and run:

library(TMB)

runExample("simple")

title: Introduction to Hyak
section: Submit a batch job to stf
text:
Submit a batch job to stf
The “driver script” runs your analysis, including loading packages, reading data, and sourceing other files with functions etc. The SLURM script specifies the resources you need and how to run your driver script. Examples of scripts that I have used:

Driver script
SLURM script

Note that these are just example scripts, I haven’t made them self-contained so they won’t run for you. That said, the fitsims.slurm file should be a good starting point for your own SLURM scripts. In the directory with the SLURM script, you can submit the job:
sbatch fitsims.slurm
Tips:

Write a single “driver” script
Use Rscript to run the driver script

title: Introduction to Hyak
section: There are three places to store files
text:
There are three places to store files

Home

\home\xyz
Persistent, but low performance
Configuration files



GScratch

\gscratch\stf\xyz
Create your own directory.
30-day limit
Scratch directory for computations



Lolo

Long-term tape storage
Must bundle files together

sshfs

git
